txt: Simon Bolivar Buckner, American general and 30th Governor of Kentucky (b. 1823)

entities.title: Simon Bolivar Buckner
entities.description: Simon Bolivar Buckner was an American soldier and politician who fought in the United States Army in the Mexican–American War and in the Confederate States Army during the American Civil War. He later served as the 30th governor of Kentucky.

entities.title: Governor of Kentucky
entities.description: The Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky is the head of Kentucky's executive branch of government. 62 men and one woman have served as Governor of Kentucky. The governor's term is four years in length; since 1992, incumbents have been able to seek re-election once before becoming ineligible for four years. Throughout the state's history, four men have served two non-consecutive terms as govern

heading: Deaths
txt: Rembrandt Bugatti, Italian sculptor (b. 1884)

entities.title: Rembrandt Bugatti
entities.description: Rembrandt Bugatti was an Italian sculptor, known primarily for his bronze sculptures of wildlife subjects. During World War I, he volunteered for paramedical work at a military hospital in Antwerp, an experience that triggered in Bugatti the onset of depression, aggravated by financial problems, which eventually caused him to commit suicide on 8 January 1916 in Paris, France. He was 31 years old.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ada Rehan, Irish-American actress (b. 1860)

heading: Deaths
txt: Ellis H. Roberts, American journalist and politician, 20th Treasurer of the United States (b. 1827)

entities.title: Ellis H. Roberts
entities.description: Ellis Henry Roberts was a United States Representative from New York and 20th Treasurer of the United States.

entities.title: Treasurer of the United States
entities.description: The Treasurer of the United States is an official in the United States Department of the Treasury who was originally charged with the receipt and custody of government funds, though many of these functions have been taken over by different bureaus of the Department. The Treasurer remains the depositary officer of the United States with regard to deposits of gold, Special Drawing Rights, and financ

heading: Deaths
txt: Josef Josephi, Polish-born singer and actor (b.1852)

entities.title: Josef Josephi
entities.description: Josef Ichhäuser(1852–1920), known by the stage name Josef Josephi (also spelled Joseffy), was a Polish-born singer (tenor-baritone) and actor.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Bellows, American painter (b.1882)

entities.title: George Bellows
entities.description: George Wesley Bellows was an American realist painter, known for his bold depictions of urban life in New York City. He became, according to the Columbus Museum of Art, "the most acclaimed American artist of his generation".

heading: Deaths
txt: Andrei Bely, Russian novelist, poet, and critic (b. 1880)

entities.title: Andrei Bely
entities.description: Boris Nikolaevich Bugaev, better known by the pen name Andrei Bely or Biely, was a Russian novelist, Symbolist poet, theorist and literary critic. He was a committed antroposophist and follower of Rudolf Steiner. His novel Petersburg was regarded by Vladimir Nabokov as the third-greatest masterpiece of the 20th century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexandre Stavisky, Ukrainian-French financier (b. 1886)

heading: Deaths
txt: Johnny Gruelle, American author and illustrator (b. 1880)

entities.title: Johnny Gruelle
entities.description: John Barton Gruelle was an American artist, political cartoonist, children's book and comics author, illustrator, and storyteller. He is best known as the creator of Raggedy Ann and Raggedy Andy dolls and as the author/illustrator of dozens of books. He also created the Beloved Belindy doll. Gruelle also contributed cartoons and illustrations to at least ten newspapers, four major news syndicates,

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Baden-Powell, 1st Baron Baden-Powell, English general and founder of the Scout movement (b. 1857)

entities.title: Robert Baden-Powell, 1st Baron Baden-Powell
entities.description: Lieutenant General Robert Stephenson Smyth Baden-Powell, 1st Baron Baden-Powell,, was a British Army officer, writer, founder and first Chief Scout of the world-wide Scout Movement, and founder, with his sister Agnes, of the world-wide Girl Guide / Girl Scout Movement. Baden-Powell authored the first editions of the seminal work Scouting for Boys, which was an inspiration for the Scout Movement.

entities.title: Scouting
entities.description: The Scout movement, also known as Scouting or the Scouts, is a voluntary non-political educational movement for young people. Although it requires an oath of allegiance to a nation's leaders and, in some countries, to a god, it otherwise allows membership without distinction of gender, race or origin in accordance with the principles of its founder, Lord Baden-Powell. The purpose of the Scout Move

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Franklin Rutherford, American lawyer and religious leader (b. 1869)

entities.title: Joseph Franklin Rutherford
entities.description: Joseph Franklin Rutherford, also known as Judge Rutherford, was the second president of the incorporated Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society of Pennsylvania. He played a primary role in the organization and doctrinal development of Jehovah's Witnesses, which emerged from the Bible Student movement established by Charles Taze Russell.

heading: Deaths
txt: Andres Larka, Estonian general and politician, 1st Estonian Minister of War (b. 1879)

entities.title: Andres Larka
entities.description: Andres Larka VR I/1 was an Estonian military commander during the Estonian War of Independence and a politician.

entities.title: Minister of Defence (Estonia)
entities.description: The Minister of Defence is the senior minister at the Ministry of Defence (Kaitseministeerium) in the Estonian Government. The Minister is one of the most important members of the Estonian government, with responsibility for coordinating the governments policies on national defence and the military forces. The Defence Minister is chosen by the Prime Minister as a part of the government.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Kissam Vanderbilt II, American lieutenant and sailor (b. 1878)

entities.title: William Kissam Vanderbilt II
entities.description: William Kissam Vanderbilt II was a motor racing enthusiast and yachtsman, and a member of the prominent American Vanderbilt family.

heading: Deaths
txt: Karl Ernst Krafft, Swiss astrologer and author (b. 1900)

entities.title: Karl Ernst Krafft
entities.description: Karl Ernst Krafft was a Swiss astrologer, born in Basel. He worked on the fields of astrology and graphology.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kurt Schwitters, German painter and graphic designer (b. 1887)

entities.title: Kurt Schwitters
entities.description: Kurt Hermann Eduard Karl Julius Schwitters was a German artist who was born in Hanover, Germany.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Schumpeter, Czech-American economist and academic (b. 1883)

entities.title: Joseph Schumpeter
entities.description: Joseph Alois Schumpeter was an Austrian political economist. He was born in Moravia, and briefly served as Finance Minister of German-Austria in 1919. In 1932, he emigrated to the United States to become a professor at Harvard University, where he remained until the end of his career, and in 1939 obtained American citizenship.

heading: Deaths
txt: Antonia Maury, American astronomer and astrophysicist (b. 1866)

entities.title: Antonia Maury
entities.description: Antonia Caetana de Paiva Pereira Maury was an American astronomer who was the first to detect and calculate the orbit of a spectroscopic binary. She published an important early catalog of stellar spectra using her own system of stellar classification, which was later adopted by the International Astronomical Union. She also spent many years studying the binary star Beta Lyrae. Maury was part of t

heading: Deaths
txt: Hugh Binney, English admiral and politician, 16th Governor of Tasmania (b. 1883)

entities.title: Hugh Binney
entities.description: Admiral Sir Thomas Hugh Binney, was a senior officer in the Royal Navy and the 16th Governor of Tasmania from 1945 to 1951.

entities.title: Governor of Tasmania
entities.description: The Governor of Tasmania is the representative in the Australian state of Tasmania of Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia. The Governor performs the same constitutional and ceremonial functions at the state level as the Governor-General of Australia does at the national level.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eduard Wiiralt, Estonian-French painter and illustrator (b. 1898)

entities.title: Eduard Wiiralt
entities.description: Eduard Wiiralt was a well-known Estonian graphic artist. In art history, Wiiralt is considered as the most remarkable master of Estonian graphic art in the first half of his century; the most well-known of his works include "Inferno", "Hell", "Cabaret", "Heads of Negroes", "Sleeping Tiger", and "Head of a Camel".

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary Colter, American architect, designed the Desert View Watchtower (b. 1869)

entities.title: Mary Colter
entities.description: Mary Elizabeth Jane Colter was an American architect and designer. She was one of the very few female American architects in her day. She was the designer of many landmark buildings and spaces for the Fred Harvey Company and the Santa Fe Railroad, notably in Grand Canyon National Park. Her work had enormous influence as she helped to create a style, blending Spanish Colonial Revival and Mission Re

entities.title: Desert View Watchtower
entities.description: Desert View Watchtower, also known as the Indian Watchtower at Desert View, is a 70-foot (21 m)-high stone building located on the South Rim of the Grand Canyon within Grand Canyon National Park in Arizona, United States. The tower is located at Desert View, more than 20 miles (32 km) to the east of the main developed area at Grand Canyon Village, toward the east entrance to the park. The four-sto

heading: Deaths
txt: Schoolboy Rowe, American baseball player and coach (b. 1910)

entities.title: Schoolboy Rowe
entities.description: Lynwood Thomas "Schoolboy" Rowe was an American right-handed pitcher in Major League Baseball, primarily for the Detroit Tigers (1932–42) and Philadelphia Phillies. He was a three-time All-Star, and a member of three Tigers' World Series teams.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kay Sage, American painter (b. 1898)

entities.title: Kay Sage
entities.description: Katherine Linn Sage, usually known as Kay Sage, was an American Surrealist artist and poet active between 1936 and 1963. A member of the Golden Age and Post-War periods of surrealism, she is mostly recognized for her artistic works, which typically contain themes of an architectural nature.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Tucker, American operatic tenor (b. 1913)

entities.title: Richard Tucker (tenor)
entities.description: Richard Tucker was an American operatic tenor.

heading: Deaths
txt: Zhou Enlai, Chinese soldier and politician, 1st Premier of the People's Republic of China (b. 1898)

entities.title: Zhou Enlai
entities.description: Zhou Enlai, Wade-Giles transliteration Chou En-lai, was the first Premier of the People's Republic of China. From October 1949 until his death in January 1976, Zhou was China's head of government. Zhou served under Chairman Mao Zedong and helped the Communist Party rise to power, later helping consolidate its control, form its foreign policy, and develop the Chinese economy.

entities.title: Premier of the People's Republic of China
entities.description: The premier of the State Council of the People's Republic of China, sometimes also referred to informally as the "prime minister", is the head of the central government of China and is the holder of the highest rank in the Civil Service. This position replaced the role of premier of the Government Administration Council of the Central People's Government, which existed from 1949 to 1954.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Mauchly, American physicist and academic (b. 1907)

entities.title: John Mauchly
entities.description: John William Mauchly was an American physicist who, along with J. Presper Eckert, designed ENIAC, the first general purpose electronic digital computer, as well as EDVAC, BINAC and UNIVAC I, the first commercial computer made in the United States.

heading: Deaths
txt: Grégoire Aslan, Swiss-English actor and screenwriter (b. 1908)

entities.title: Grégoire Aslan
entities.description: Grégoire Aslan was an Armenian actor and musician based in Switzerland.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gerhard Barkhorn, German general and pilot (b. 1919)

entities.title: Gerhard Barkhorn
entities.description: Gerhard "Gerd" Barkhorn was a German military aviator and wing commander in the Luftwaffe during World War II. As a fighter ace, he was the second most successful fighter pilot of all time after fellow pilot Erich Hartmann. Other than Hartmann, Barkhorn is the only fighter ace to ever exceed 300 claimed victories. Following World War II, he became a high-ranking officer in the German Air Force of

heading: Deaths
txt: Pierre Fournier, French cellist and educator (b. 1906)

entities.title: Pierre Fournier
entities.description: Pierre Léon Marie Fournier was a French cellist who was called the "aristocrat of cellists," on account of his elegant musicianship and majestic sound.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bernard Krigstein, American illustrator (b. 1919)

entities.title: Bernard Krigstein
entities.description: Bernard Krigstein, was an American illustrator and gallery artist who received acclaim for his innovative and influential approach to comic book art, notably in EC Comics. His artwork usually displayed the signature B. Krigstein. His best-known work in comic books is the eight-page story "Master Race", originally published in the debut issue of EC Comics' Impact.

heading: Deaths
txt: Terry-Thomas, English actor and comedian (b. 1911)

heading: Deaths
txt: Steve Clark, English singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1960)

entities.title: Steve Clark
entities.description: Stephen Maynard Clark was an English musician. He was the principal songwriter and lead guitarist for the English hard rock band Def Leppard until 1991, when he died from alcohol poisoning. In 2007, Clark was ranked No. 11 on Classic Rock Magazine's "100 Wildest Guitar Heroes". In 2019, Clark was posthumously inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as a member of Def Leppard.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pat Buttram, American actor and comedian (b. 1915)

entities.title: Pat Buttram
entities.description: Maxwell Emmett Buttram, professionally known as Pat Buttram, was an American character actor, known for playing the sidekick of Gene Autry and for playing the character of Mr. Haney in the television series Green Acres. He had a distinctive voice that, in his own words, "never quite made it through puberty."

heading: Deaths
txt: Harvey Haddix, American baseball player and coach (b. 1925)

heading: Deaths
txt: Metin Göktepe, Turkish photographer and journalist (b. 1968)

entities.title: Metin Göktepe
entities.description: Metin Göktepe was a Turkish photojournalist who was tortured and brutally murdered in police custody in Istanbul on January 8, 1996.

heading: Deaths
txt: François Mitterrand, French sergeant and politician, 21st President of France (b. 1916)

entities.title: President of France
entities.description: The president of France, officially the president of the French Republic, is the head of state and head of executive of France as well as the commander-in-chief of the French Armed Forces. The French presidency is the supreme magistracy of the country, and the president is the holder of the highest office in France.

heading: Deaths
txt: Melvin Calvin, American chemist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1911)

entities.title: Melvin Calvin
entities.description: Melvin Ellis Calvin was an American biochemist known for discovering the Calvin cycle along with Andrew Benson and James Bassham, for which he was awarded the 1961 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. He spent most of his five-decade career at the University of California, Berkeley.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. This award is administered by the Nobel Foundation, and awarded by t

heading: Deaths
txt: Michael Tippett, English composer and conductor (b. 1905)

entities.title: Michael Tippett
entities.description: Sir Michael Kemp Tippett was an English composer who rose to prominence during and immediately after the Second World War. In his lifetime he was sometimes ranked with his contemporary Benjamin Britten as one of the leading British composers of the 20th century. Among his best-known works are the oratorio A Child of Our Time, the orchestral Fantasia Concertante on a Theme of Corelli, and the opera

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Prokhorov, Australian-Russian physicist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1916)

entities.title: Alexander Prokhorov
entities.description: Alexander Mikhailovich Prokhorov was an Australian-born Soviet-Russian physicist known for his pioneering research on lasers and masers in the Soviet Union for which he shared the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1964 with Charles Hard Townes and Nikolay Basov.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

heading: Deaths
txt: Dave Thomas, American businessman and philanthropist, founded Wendy's (b. 1932)

entities.title: Wendy's
entities.description: Wendy's is an American international fast food restaurant chain founded by Dave Thomas on November 15, 1969, in Columbus, Ohio. The company moved its headquarters to Dublin, Ohio, on January 29, 2006. As of December 31, 2018, Wendy's was the world's third-largest hamburger fast-food chain with 6,711 locations, following Burger King and McDonald's. On April 24, 2008, the company announced a merger

heading: Deaths
txt: Ron Goodwin, English composer and conductor (b. 1925)

entities.title: Ron Goodwin
entities.description: Ronald Alfred Goodwin was an English composer and conductor known for his film music. He scored over 70 films in a career lasting over fifty years. His most famous works included Where Eagles Dare, Battle of Britain, 633 Squadron, Margaret Rutherford's Miss Marple films, and Frenzy.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tony Banks, Baron Stratford, Northern Irish broadcaster and politician, Minister for Sport and the Olympics (b. 1943)

entities.title: Tony Banks, Baron Stratford
entities.description: Anthony Louis Banks, Baron Stratford was a British Labour politician who served as a member of Parliament from 1983 to 2005 and subsequently as a member of the House of Lords. He served as Minister for Sport from 1997 to 1999. He was well known in the House of Commons for his acid tongue.

entities.title: Minister for Sport and the Olympics
entities.description: The Minister for Sport is a junior minister in the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport of the United Kingdom government, with responsibility for sport and Civil Society in England. The office is currently held by Nigel Huddleston.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jane Bolin, American lawyer and judge (b. 1908)

entities.title: Jane Bolin
entities.description: Jane Matilda Bolin, LL.B. was the first black woman to graduate from Yale Law School, the first to join the New York City Bar Association and the first to join the New York City Law Department. She became the first black woman to serve as a judge in the United States when she was sworn into the bench of the New York City Domestic Relations Court in 1939.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arthur Cockfield, Baron Cockfield, English lawyer and politician, Secretary of State for Business, Innovation and Skills (b. 1916)

entities.title: Secretary of State for Business, Innovation and Skills
entities.description: The Secretary of State for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy, also referred to as the Business Secretary, is a senior Minister of the Crown within the Government of the United Kingdom, and head of the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS). The office was created under its present name in 2016 and forms part of the Cabinet of the United Kingdom.

heading: Deaths
txt: Yvonne De Carlo, Canadian-American actress and singer (b. 1922)

heading: Deaths
txt: David Ervine, Northern Irish politician and activist (b. 1953)

heading: Deaths
txt: Iwao Takamoto, American animator, director, and producer (b. 1925)

heading: Deaths
txt: George Moore, Australian jockey and trainer (b. 1923)

entities.title: George Moore (jockey)
entities.description: George Thomas Donald Moore OBE was an Australian jockey and Thoroughbred horse trainer. He began his career in racing in 1939 in Brisbane where he quickly became one of the top apprentice jockeys and where in 1943 he won the Senior Jockeys' Premiership. He then relocated to Sydney and in 1949 went to work for trainer Tommy J. Smith with whom he would have considerable success.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lasantha Wickrematunge, Sri Lankan journalist (b. 1958)

entities.title: Lasantha Wickrematunge
entities.description: Lasantha Manilal Wickrematunge was a Sri Lankan journalist, politician and human rights activist who was assassinated in January 2009.

heading: Deaths
txt: Art Clokey, American animator, director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1921)

entities.title: Art Clokey
entities.description: Arthur "Art" Clokey was an American pioneer in the popularization of stop-motion clay animation, best known as the creator of the character Gumby and the original voice of Gumby's sidekick, Pokey. Clokey's career began in 1953 with a film experiment called Gumbasia, which was influenced by his professor, Slavko Vorkapich, at the University of Southern California. Clokey and his wife Ruth subsequen

heading: Deaths
txt: Jiří Dienstbier, Czech journalist and politician (b. 1937)

entities.title: Jiří Dienstbier
entities.description: Jiří Dienstbier was a Czech politician and journalist. Born in Kladno, he was one of Czechoslovakia's most respected foreign correspondents before being fired after the Prague Spring. Unable to have a livelihood as a journalist, he worked as a janitor for the next two decades. During this time, he secretly revived the suppressed Lidové noviny newspaper.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thorbjørn Svenssen, Norwegian footballer (b. 1924)

heading: Deaths
txt: Dave Alexander, American singer and pianist (b. 1938)

entities.title: Dave Alexander (blues musician)
entities.description: Dave Alexander, also known as Omar Sharriff, Omar Shariff, Omar Hakim Khayam was an American West Coast blues singer and pianist.

txt: T. J. Hamblin, English haematologist and academic (b. 1943)

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexis Weissenberg, Bulgarian-French pianist and educator (b. 1929)

heading: Deaths
txt: Kenojuak Ashevak, Canadian sculptor and illustrator (b. 1927)

entities.title: Kenojuak Ashevak
entities.description: Kenojuak Ashevak, is celebrated as a leading figure of modern Inuit art.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jeanne Manford, American educator and activist, co-founded PFLAG (b. 1920)

entities.title: PFLAG
entities.description: PFLAG is the United States' first and largest organization uniting parents, families, and allies with people who are lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ+). PFLAG National is the national organization, which provides support to the PFLAG network of local chapters. PFLAG has over 400 chapters across the United States, with more than 200,000 members and supporters.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alasdair Milne, Indian-English director and producer (b. 1930)

heading: Deaths
txt: Irma Heijting-Schuhmacher, Dutch-Australian swimmer (b. 1925)

entities.title: Irma Heijting-Schuhmacher
entities.description: Irma Heijting-Schuhmacher was a freestyle swimmer from the Netherlands who won two medals at the Summer Olympics. After having claimed the bronze medal in the 4 × 100 m freestyle relay in London (1948), she won the silver medal four years later in Helsinki, Finland, in the same event. Individually, she was sixth in the 100 m freestyle at both games. She also won two gold and two silver medals at t

heading: Deaths
txt: Antonino P. Roman, Filipino lawyer and politician (b. 1939)

heading: Deaths
txt: Andraé Crouch, American singer-songwriter, producer, and pastor (b. 1942)

entities.title: Andraé Crouch
entities.description: Andraé Edward Crouch was an American gospel singer, songwriter, arranger, record producer and pastor. Referred to as "the father of modern gospel music" by contemporary Christian and gospel music professionals, Crouch was known for his compositions "The Blood Will Never Lose Its Power", "My Tribute " and "Soon and Very Soon". He collaborated on some of his recordings with famous and popular artist

heading: Deaths
txt: Kep Enderby, Australian lawyer, judge, and politician, 23rd Attorney-General for Australia (b. 1926)

entities.title: Attorney-General for Australia
entities.description: The Attorney-General of Australia is the First Law Officer of the Crown in right of the Commonwealth of Australia, chief law officer of the Commonwealth of Australia and a minister of state. The Attorney-General is usually a member of the Federal Cabinet, but need not be. Under the Constitution, they are appointed by the Governor-General on the advice of the Prime Minister, and serve at the Govern

heading: Deaths
txt: Patsy Garrett, American actress and singer (b. 1921)

heading: Deaths
txt: Maria Teresa de Filippis, Italian racing driver (b. 1926)

entities.title: Maria Teresa de Filippis
entities.description: Maria Teresa de Filippis was an Italian racing driver, and the first woman to race in Formula One. She participated in five World Championship Grands Prix, debuting on 18 May 1958, but scored no championship points. Though her Formula One racing career was brief, she won races in other series and is remembered as a pioneer in the sport.

heading: Deaths
txt: German Moreno, Filipino television host, actor, comedian and talent manager (b. 1933)

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicolai Gedda, Swedish operatic tenor (b. 1925)

entities.title: Nicolai Gedda
entities.description: Harry Gustaf Nikolai Gädda, known professionally as Nicolai Gedda, was a Swedish operatic tenor. Debuting in 1951, Gedda had a long and successful career in opera until the age of 77 in June 2003, when he made his final operatic recording. Skilled at languages, he performed operas in French, Russian, German, Italian, English, Czech and Swedish, as well as one in Latin. In January 1958, he created

heading: Deaths
txt: James Mancham, Seychellois politician, President 1976-77 (b. 1939)

heading: Deaths
txt: Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, Iranian politician (b. 1934)

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Sarstedt, Indian-British singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1941)

heading: Deaths
txt: Pat Dalton, Australian footballer (b. 1942)

entities.title: Pat Dalton
entities.description: Patrick James Dalton was an Australian rules footballer who played 217 games for Perth in the WANFL from 1960-71. He was named on the interchange bench in Perth's official "Team of the Century". A regular for Perth during the 1960s, Dalton was almost always used as a centreman. He was a member of three consecutive premiership teams at Perth, in 1966, 1967 and 1968.

heading: Deaths
txt: Buck Henry, American actor, screenwriter, and director (b. 1930)

heading: Deaths
txt: Iancu Țucărman, Romanian Holocaust survivor (b. 1922)

entities.title: Iancu Țucărman
entities.description: Iancu Țucărman was a Romanian Jewish agricultural engineer and survivor of the Holocaust and the Iași pogrom. He died in 8 January 2021 at age 98 after getting infected by COVID-19 during the COVID-19 pandemic in Romania.
